bibliography.source_title: Aerosol pH and chemical regimes of sulfate formation in aerosol water during winter haze in the North China Plain
bibliography.source_authors: Tao, W., Su, H., Zheng, G., Wang, J., Wei, C., Liu, L., Ma, N., Li, M., Zhang, Q., Pöschl, U., and Cheng, Y.
bibliography.key_findings: Aerosol pH exhibits strong vertical gradient (pH ~5.4 at surface to ~0 at 3km). Different sulfate formation pathways dominate at different pH ranges: NO2/O3 at pH>4.5, TMI/H2O2 at pH<4.5. Rapid sulfate production maintained over pH 4.2-5.7 with pathway transitions.

bibliography.source_title: Sulfate formation is dominated by manganese-catalyzed oxidation of SO2 on aerosol surfaces during haze events
bibliography.source_authors: Wang, W., Liu, M., Wang, T., Song, Y., Zhou, L., Cao, J., Hu, J., Tang, G., Chen, Z., Li, Z., Xu, Z., Peng, C., Lian, C., Chen, Y., Pan, Y., Zhang, Y., Sun, Y., Li, W., Zhu, T., Tian, H., Ge, M.
bibliography.key_findings: Mn-catalyzed SO2 oxidation on aerosol surfaces contributes 69.2% ± 5.0% of particulate sulfur production during haze. Rate is 1-2 orders of magnitude larger than previously known routes. Sulfate formation rate: 14.1-24.5 μg m-3 h-1.

bibliography.source_title: Aerosol high water contents favor sulfate and secondary organic aerosol formation from fossil fuel combustion emissions
bibliography.source_authors: Huang, X., Liu, Z., Ge, Y., Li, Q., Wang, X., Fu, H., Zhu, J., Zhou, B., Wang, L., George, C., Wang, Y., Wang, X., Su, J., Xue, L., Yu, S., Mellouki, A., Chen, J.
bibliography.key_findings: High aerosol water content promotes EC particle aging and SOA formation. Under RH>85%, multiphase SO2 oxidation by in-particle nitrite/HONO leads to substantial sulfate increase. PM2.5 mass 2.0-4.3x higher during high RH episodes.

bibliography.source_title: Mineral dust and NOx promote the conversion of SO2 to sulfate in heavy pollution days
bibliography.source_authors: He, H., Wang, Y., Ma, Q., Ma, J., Chu, B., Ji, D., Tang, G., Liu, C., Zhang, H., Hao, J.
bibliography.key_findings: NO2 and SO2 have synergistic effects on mineral dust surfaces. Coexistence of NO2 significantly promotes sulfite to sulfate oxidation. O2 is the key oxidant in the process. Sulfate formation is main reason for fine particle growth.

bibliography.source_title: Importance of gas-particle partitioning of ammonia in haze formation in the rural agricultural environment
bibliography.source_authors: Xu, J., Chen, J., Zhao, N., Wang, G., Yu, G., Li, H., Huo, J., Lin, Y., Fu, Q., Guo, H., Deng, C., Lee, S.-H., Chen, J., Huang, K.
bibliography.key_findings: Gas-particle partitioning of ammonia ε(NH4+), not ammonia concentration, plays critical role in SNA formation. AWC plays predominant role in regulating ε(NH4+). Self-amplifying feedback mechanism: higher AWC → higher ε(NH4+) → more SNA → more AWC.

bibliography.source_title: Aqueous production of secondary organic aerosol from fossil-fuel emissions in winter Beijing haze
bibliography.source_authors: Wang, J., et al.
bibliography.key_findings: Fast aqueous-phase oxidation of POA at high RH forms SOA. Ring-breaking oxidation of PAHs leads to functionalization as carbonyls and carboxylic acids. Aq-SOA accounts for ~20% of total OA in haze events.

bibliography.source_title: Influence of Secondary Inorganic Aerosol on the Concentrations of PM2.5 and PM0.1 during Air Pollution Episodes in Hanoi, Vietnam
bibliography.source_authors: Nguyen-Quoc Dat, Bich-Thuy Ly, Trung-Dung Nghiem, Thu-Thi Hien Nguyen, Kazuhiko Sekiguchi, Truong-Thi Huyen, Thai-Ha Vinh, Le-Quang Tien
bibliography.key_findings: SIA contributed on average 29.0% and 14.1% to PM2.5 and PM0.1 concentrations during air pollution episodes in Hanoi. Relative humidity, pressure, temperature, and radiation had good correlation with SIA of PM0.1.

bibliography.source_title: Chemical composition and potential sources of PM2.5 in Hanoi
bibliography.source_authors: Ulla Makkonen, Mika Vestenius, L.N. Huy, N.T.N. Anh, P.T.V. Linh, P.T. Thuy, H.T.M. Phuong, Huyen Nguyen, L.T. Thuy, Minna Aurela, Heidi Hellén, Katja Loven, Rostislav Kouznetsov, Katriina Kyllönen, Kimmo Teinilä, N.T. Kim Oanh
bibliography.key_findings: One third of PM2.5 mass was secondary inorganic aerosol dominated by sulphates. PMF analysis identified six source factors including local SIA (18%) and long-range transported SIA (25%).

bibliography.source_title: Fast sulfate formation from oxidation of SO2 by NO2 and HONO observed in Beijing haze
bibliography.source_authors: Junfeng Wang, Jingyi Li, Jianhuai Ye, et al.
bibliography.key_findings: High relative humidity conditions enable fast aqueous-phase oxidation of SO2 by NO2 with pH > 5.5. HONO can oxidize SO2 to yield N2O and sulfate.

bibliography.source_title: Multiphase Oxidation of Sulfur Dioxide in Aerosol Particles: Implications for Sulfate Formation in Polluted Environments
bibliography.source_authors: Tengyu Liu, Arthur W. H. Chan, Jonathan P. D. Abbatt
bibliography.key_findings: Multiphase oxidation of SO2 in aerosol particles involves H2O2, O3, NO2, and transition metal ion catalyzed reactions. Aerosol liquid water content and pH are critical factors.

bibliography.source_title: Relative humidity and temperature dependence of the ammonium nitrate dissociation constant
bibliography.source_authors: A.W. Stelson, J.H. Seinfeld
bibliography.key_findings: NH4NO3 dissociation constant depends on temperature and relative humidity. Lower temperature and higher RH favor particle phase NH4NO3 formation.

bibliography.source_title: Characteristics of Chemical Components in Fine Particles (PM2.5) and Ultrafine Particles (PM0.1) in Hanoi, Vietnam
bibliography.source_authors: Truong-Thi Huyen, Ryosuke Yamaguchi, Yuta Kurotsuchi, Kazuhiko Sekiguchi, Nguyen-Thi Dung, Nguyen-Thi Thu Thuy, Le-Bich Thuy
bibliography.key_findings: The correlations between relative humidity and chemical components suggest that PM2.5 collected in Hanoi was formed through secondary formation processes. High humidity promotes aqueous-phase reactions.

bibliography.source_title: Photochemical environment over Southeast Asia primed for hazardous ozone levels with influx of nitrogen oxides from seasonal biomass burning
bibliography.source_authors: M.R. Marvin, P.I. Palmer, B.G. Latter, et al.
bibliography.key_findings: Pyrogenic emissions of NOx play a key role in photochemistry in Southeast Asia, shifting towards more VOC-limited ozone production and contributing about 30% to O3 formation.

bibliography.source_title: Intricate behavior of winter pollution in Hanoi over the 2006–2020 semi-climatic period
bibliography.source_authors: Phung-Ngoc, B.A., Dieudonné, E., Delbarre, H., Deboudt, K., Nguyen, S.T., Bui, V.H., Vu, D.M., Nguyen-Thi, H.T.
bibliography.key_findings: Primary source on cold surge onset/persistence mechanisms in Hanoi with quantified PM2.5 impacts

bibliography.source_title: A Study of Urban Haze and Its Association with Cold Surge and Sea Breeze for Greater Bangkok
bibliography.source_authors: Aman, N., Manomaiphiboon, K., Pala-En, N., Devkota, B., Inerb, M., Kokkaew, E.
bibliography.source_journal: Int J Environ Res Public Health, 20(4):3482
bibliography.key_findings: Classification of haze types by cold surge and sea breeze interactions in Southeast Asia

bibliography.source_title: Characterizing PM2.5 in Hanoi with New High Temporal Resolution Sensor
bibliography.source_authors: Ly, B.T., Matsumi, Y., Nakayama, T., Sakamoto, Y., Kajii, Y., Nghiem, T.D.
bibliography.key_findings: High-resolution PM2.5 measurements showing post-cold surge secondary aerosol formation

bibliography.source_title: Air pollution episodes associated with East Asian winter monsoons
bibliography.source_authors: Hien, P.D., Loc, P.D., Dao, N.V.
bibliography.key_findings: Foundational study on winter pollution episodes and monsoon cycle mechanisms in Hanoi

bibliography.source_title: Key factors explaining severe air pollution episodes in Hanoi during 2019 winter season
bibliography.source_authors: Ngoc, B.A.P., Delbarre, H., Deboudt, K., Dieudonné, E., Tran, D.N., Thanh, S.L., Pelon, J., Ravetta, F.
bibliography.key_findings: Lidar measurements showing boundary layer height role in cold surge-PM2.5 relationship

bibliography.source_title: Large-scale transport of PM2.5 in the lower troposphere during winter cold surges in China
bibliography.source_authors: Wang, J., Zhang, M., Bai, X., et al.
bibliography.key_findings: Quantified long-range PM2.5 transport mechanisms during cold surges (2000 km in 2 days)

bibliography.source_title: The effects of meteorological conditions and long-range transport on PM2.5 levels in Hanoi revealed from multi-site measurement using compact sensors and machine learning approach
bibliography.source_authors: Ly, B.T., Matsumi, Y., Vu, T.V., et al.
bibliography.key_findings: Machine learning analysis of meteorological and transport contributions to PM2.5

bibliography.source_title: Relationships of relative humidity with PM2.5 and PM10 in the Yangtze River Delta, China
bibliography.source_authors: Cairong Lou, Hongyu Liu, Yufeng Li, Yan Peng, Juan Wang & Lingjun Dai
bibliography.key_findings: Identified an inverted U-shaped relationship between RH and PM2.5, with a peak at 45-70% RH. Above 70% RH, the effect turns into reduction. This establishes a critical non-linear relationship and threshold.

bibliography.source_title: Effect of precipitation on reducing atmospheric pollutant over Beijing
bibliography.source_authors: Zuofang Zheng, Guirong Xu, Qingchun Li, Conglan Chen, Jiangbo Li
bibliography.key_findings: Explicitly states that drizzle has a negative removal effect on PM2.5 (i.e., it can increase concentrations), which is a direct exception to the general rule that rain cleans the air.

bibliography.source_title: Characterizing PM2.5 in Hanoi with New High Temporal Resolution Sensor
bibliography.source_authors: Bich-Thuy Ly, Yutaka Matsumi, Tomoki Nakayama, Yosuke Sakamoto, Yoshizumi Kajii, Trung-Dung Nghiem
bibliography.key_findings: Observed in Hanoi that large increases in PM2.5 frequently occur several days (4-5 days) after a cold surge, demonstrating a delayed, non-linear effect.

bibliography.source_title: Rapid reappearance of air pollution after cold air outbreaks in northern and eastern China
bibliography.source_authors: Qian Liu, Guixing Chen, Lifang Sheng, and Toshiki Iwasaki
bibliography.key_findings: Explains the mechanism for the post-cold surge pollution spike, attributing it to stable stratification in the lower troposphere forced by the residual cold air mass.

bibliography.source_title: Effect of Vertical Wind Shear on PM2.5 Changes over a Receptor Region in Central China
bibliography.source_authors: Xiaoyun Sun, Yue Zhou, Tianliang Zhao, Yongqing Bai, Tao Huo, Liang Leng, Huan He, Jing Sun
bibliography.key_findings: Shows that the correlation between wind speed and PM2.5 can be positive under polluted conditions, indicating that strong winds can increase pollution at a receptor site via long-range transport.

bibliography.source_title: Hygroscopic properties of particulate matter and effects of their interactions with weather on visibility
bibliography.source_authors: Wan-Sik Won, Rosy Oh, Woojoo Lee, Sungkwan Ku, Pei-Chen Su, Yong-Jin Yoon
bibliography.key_findings: Explains the mechanism of hygroscopic growth, where particles absorb water at high RH, increasing their size and causing light-scattering-based sensors to overestimate PM2.5 mass. This is a key measurement artifact.

bibliography.source_title: Disentangling fine particles (PM2.5) composition in Hanoi, Vietnam: Combined PMF analysis of filter and ACSM measurements
bibliography.source_authors: Dominutti, P.A., Cohen, D.D., Stelcer, E., et al.
bibliography.key_findings: Source apportionment study identifying traffic (10-15%), industry (10-15%), coal combustion (10-15%), biomass burning (15-20%), and secondary aerosols (30-40%) as major PM2.5 sources in Hanoi. Vietnam experienced 11% annual growth in coal consumption 2011-2021.

bibliography.source_title: Impact of Covid-19 partial lockdown on PM2.5, SO2, NO2, O3, and trace elements in PM2.5 in Hanoi, Vietnam
bibliography.source_authors: Nguyen, T.P.M., Bui, T.H., Nguyen, M.K., et al.
bibliography.key_findings: COVID-19 lockdown reduced NO2 by 75.8%, PM2.5 by 55.9%, SO2 by 60.7%. Traffic identified as major mobile source. Industrial activities (stationary sources) remained stable during lockdown. Motorbike exhaust is major NO2 source.

bibliography.source_title: Emission factors of selected air pollutants from rice straw burning in Hanoi, Vietnam
bibliography.source_authors: Pham, C.T., Ly, B.T., Nghiem, T.D., et al.
bibliography.key_findings: Rice straw open burning (RSOB) emission factors: PM2.5 = 34.0 ± 17.6 g/kg rice straw. Annual emissions in Hanoi: 10.8 Gg PM2.5, 0.67 Gg SO2, 0.35 Gg NO2, 13.7 Gg CO. Higher than Thailand and China.

bibliography.source_title: Chemical characterization, source apportionment, and human health risk assessment of PM2.5 in an urban area in Hanoi, Vietnam
bibliography.source_authors: Bui, T.H., Nguyen, D.L., Nguyen, T.P.M., et al.
bibliography.key_findings: PCA+EF analysis identified major PM2.5 sources: non-exhaust traffic emission and crustal dust, exhaust traffic emission, coal combustion, and industrial source. Al, Fe, Pb, Zn account for 85-89% of trace elements.

bibliography.source_title: Assessing the Impact of Traffic Emissions on Fine Particulate Matter and Carbon Monoxide Levels in Hanoi through COVID-19 Social Distancing Periods
bibliography.source_authors: Le, N.H., Ly, B.T., Thai, P.K., et al.
bibliography.key_findings: Traffic primary emissions reduced 37-60% for PM2.5 and 33-49% for CO during social distancing. CO at traffic sites was double urban sites. PM2.5 reduced 14-18% during lockdown. Coal-fired power plants remained stable.

bibliography.source_title: Chemical composition and potential sources of PM2.5 in Hanoi
bibliography.source_authors: Makkonen, U., Vestenius, M., Huy, L.N., et al.
bibliography.key_findings: PMF analysis: Traffic 12%, Local SIA 18%, Biomass burning 19%, Industry 9%, Long-range transported SIA 25%, Dust 17%. Half of PM2.5 is organic matter (40% from biomass burning). One third is secondary inorganic aerosol dominated by sulphate (coal combustion indicator).

bibliography.source_title: Air Quality in Hanoi: Current Situation & Policy Intervention
bibliography.source_authors: The World Bank & Hanoi Department of Natural Resources & Environment
bibliography.key_findings: Primary PM2.5 sources in Hanoi: Industrial activities 29%, Open burning of rice straw 26%, Road dust 23%, Transport 15%. Only one third of PM2.5 from local sources; rest transported from Greater Hanoi, Red River Delta, other provinces.

bibliography.source_title: Effects of Gas and Steam Humidity on Particulate Matter Measurements Obtained Using Light-Scattering Sensors
bibliography.source_authors: Kim, H., Kim, J., Roh, S.
bibliography.key_findings: Steam humidity (fog) causes errors in PM measurement via light-scattering method, while gaseous humidity does not

bibliography.source_title: The influence of humidity on the performance of a low-cost air particle mass sensor and the effect of atmospheric fog
bibliography.source_authors: Jayaratne, R., Liu, X., Thai, P., Dunbabin, M., Morawska, L.
bibliography.key_findings: Sensor overestimation increases by factor of 2-3 at RH > 85% due to hygroscopic particle growth

bibliography.source_title: Important Role of Low Cloud and Fog in Sulfate Aerosol Formation During Winter Haze Over the North China Plain
bibliography.source_authors: Cai, S., Liu, T., Huang, X., Song, Y., Wang, T., Sun, Z., Gao, J., Ding, A.
bibliography.key_findings: High sulfur oxidation ratios (>0.6) under heavily polluted conditions are associated with low clouds and fog

bibliography.source_title: Fast sulfate formation from oxidation of SO2 by NO2 and HONO observed in Beijing haze
bibliography.source_authors: Wang, J., Li, J., Ye, J., Zhao, J., Wu, Y., Hu, J., Liu, D., Nie, D., Shen, F., Huang, X., et al.
bibliography.key_findings: Fog and cloud with high pH (>5.5) enable fast aqueous-phase oxidation of SO2 by NO2

bibliography.source_title: Particle phase state and aerosol liquid water greatly impact secondary aerosol formation: insights into phase transition and its role in haze events
bibliography.source_authors: Meng, X., Wu, Z., Chen, J., Qiu, Y., Zong, T., Song, M., Lee, J., Hu, M.
bibliography.key_findings: Sulfate and nitrate transformation rates increase by 48% and 11% respectively during phase transition

bibliography.source_title: Reactive nitrogen chemistry in aerosol water as a source of sulfate during haze events in China
bibliography.source_authors: Cheng, Y., Zheng, G., Wei, C., Mu, Q., Zheng, B., Wang, Z., Gao, M., Zhang, Q., He, K., Carmichael, G., Pöschl, U., Su, H.
bibliography.key_findings: Synergistic effect between NOx and SO2 in aqueous phase explains rapid sulfate formation during severe haze

bibliography.source_title: Tracing the Formation of Secondary Aerosols Influenced by Solar Radiation and Relative Humidity in Suburban Environment
bibliography.source_authors: Wu, Y., Liu, D., Tian, P., Sheng, J., Liu, Q., Li, R., Hu, K., Jiang, X., Li, S., Bi, K., Zhao, D., Huang, M., Ding, D., Wang, J.
bibliography.key_findings: OOA production rate reached 15.0% h⁻¹ under intense solar radiation

bibliography.source_title: Differences in fine particle chemical composition on clear and cloudy days
bibliography.source_authors: Christiansen, A.E., Carlton, A.G., Henderson, B.H.
bibliography.key_findings: Clear-sky PM2.5 concentrations are generally higher than cloudy with some exceptions during winter

bibliography.source_title: Nocturnal surface radiation cooling modulated by cloud cover change reinforces PM2.5 accumulation: Observational study of heavy air pollution in the Sichuan Basin, Southwest China
bibliography.source_authors: Jun Hu, Tianliang Zhao, Jane Liu, Le Cao, Junrong Xia, Chenggang Wang, Xingbing Zhao, Zhiqiu Gao, Zhuozhi Shu, Yueqing Li
bibliography.key_findings: Demonstrates that decreased cloud cover enhances surface radiation cooling at night, which strengthens temperature inversion and promotes PM2.5 accumulation. Provides quantitative evidence for cloud-radiation-inversion-PM2.5 pathway.

bibliography.source_title: Tracing the Formation of Secondary Aerosols Influenced by Solar Radiation and Relative Humidity in Suburban Environment
bibliography.source_authors: Yangzhou Wu, Dantong Liu, Ping Tian, Jiujiang Sheng, Quan Liu, et al.
bibliography.key_findings: Shows that solar radiation drives photochemical aging and OOA (secondary organic aerosol) formation. Higher solar radiation leads to faster SOA production. Reduced solar radiation (from clouds/pollution) decreases photochemical reaction rates.

bibliography.source_title: Formation of hydroxyl radicals from photolysis of secondary organic aerosol material
bibliography.source_authors: K. M. Badali, S. Zhou, D. Aljawhary, M. Antiñolo, W. J. Chen, A. Lok, E. Mungall, J. P. S. Wong, R. Zhao, J. P. D. Abbatt
bibliography.key_findings: Demonstrates that UV photolysis of SOA material produces OH radicals with high quantum yield (0.8 ± 0.4). OH formation rates from SOA are 5 times faster than from H2O2 photolysis alone.

bibliography.source_title: Impacts of atmospheric circulation patterns and cloud inhibition on aerosol radiative effect and boundary layer structure during winter air pollution in Sichuan Basin, China
bibliography.source_authors: Hua Lu, Min Xie, Bingliang Zhuang, Danyang Ma, Bojun Liu, Yangzhihao Zhan, Tijian Wang, Shu Li, Mengmeng Li, Kuanguang Zhu
bibliography.key_findings: Quantifies cloud radiation interaction (CRI) effects: clouds reduce solar radiation through reflection and scattering, causing 50% reduction in solar radiation and boundary layer height. CRI inhibition leads to more stable stratification and aerosol accumulation.

bibliography.source_title: Impacts of aerosol–photolysis interaction and aerosol–radiation feedback on surface-layer ozone in North China during multi-pollutant air pollution episodes
bibliography.source_authors: Hao Yang, Lei Chen, Hong Liao, Jia Zhu, Wenjie Wang, Xin Li
bibliography.key_findings: Quantifies aerosol-photolysis interaction: reduced solar radiation decreases photolysis rates (J[NO2], J[O1D]) by 1.8-2.0×10⁻³ and 5.7-6.4×10⁻⁶ s⁻¹ respectively. This reduces O3 production and affects secondary aerosol formation.

bibliography.source_title: Influence of meteorological conditions on PM2.5 and PM2.5−10 concentrations during the monsoon season in Hanoi, Vietnam
bibliography.source_authors: P.D. Hien, V.T. Bac, H.C. Tham, D.D. Nhan, L.D. Vinh
bibliography.key_findings: Foundational paper for Hanoi: nocturnal radiation inversions (Oct-Dec) and subsidence temperature inversions (Jan-Mar) cause very high PM2.5. Meteorological parameters explain 60-74% of day-to-day PM2.5 variations.

bibliography.source_title: Aqueous-phase mechanism for secondary organic aerosol formation from isoprene: application to the southeast United States and co-benefit of SO2 emission controls
bibliography.source_authors: Marais, E. A., Jacob, D. J., Jimenez, J. L., Campuzano-Jost, P., Day, D. A., Hu, W., Krechmer, J., Zhu, L., Kim, P. S., Miller, C. C., Fisher, J. A., Travis, K., Yu, K., Hanisco, T. F., Wolfe, G. M., Arkinson, H. L., Pye, H. O. T., Froyd, K. D., Liao, J., McNeill, V. F.
bibliography.key_findings: Isoprene SOA formation via IEPOX pathway contributes 58% of isoprene SOA under low-NOx conditions. Mean SOA mass yield of 3.3% from isoprene oxidation. Strong relationship between IEPOX SOA and sulfate aerosol due to aerosol acidity effects.

bibliography.source_title: Multiple pathways for the formation of secondary organic aerosol in the North China Plain in summer
bibliography.source_authors: Gu, Y., Huang, R.-J., Duan, J., Xu, W., Lin, C., Zhong, H., Wang, Y., Ni, H., Liu, Q., Xu, R., Wang, L., Li, Y. J.
bibliography.key_findings: SOA formation via photochemistry (Ox-initiated) dominated daytime with 0.8 µg/m³/h growth rate. Aqueous-phase SOA formation significant during high-RH periods with 0.6 µg/m³/h nighttime growth rate. Photochemistry in aqueous phase also non-negligible (0.6 µg/m³/h).

bibliography.source_title: Effect of clouds on photolysis and oxidants in the troposphere
bibliography.source_authors: Tie, X., Madronich, S., Walters, S., Zhang, R., Rasch, P., Collins, W.
bibliography.key_findings: Clouds increase global mean OH concentration by ~20%. Photolysis rates J[O3], J[CH2O], J[NO2] enhanced by 12-13% due to clouds. Tropospheric O3 concentrations increase by 8% due to cloud effects on photolysis.

bibliography.source_title: Secondary organic aerosol formation in cloud droplets and aqueous particles (aqSOA): a review of laboratory, field and model studies
bibliography.source_authors: Ervens, B., Turpin, B. J., Weber, R. J.
bibliography.key_findings: aqSOA might contribute almost as much mass as gasSOA to the SOA budget. Highest contributions from biogenic VOC emissions in presence of anthropogenic NOx at high RH and cloudiness. Cloud/fog processing produces dicarboxylic acids and humic-like substances.

bibliography.source_title: Re-assessing hydroxyl radical chemistry in the atmosphere: Instrument interferences may explain previous measurement discrepancies
bibliography.source_authors: Price, P., Bottorff, B., Jenkins, J., Brune, W. H., Stevens, P. S.
bibliography.key_findings: OH radical production primarily driven by photolysis of ozone and HONO. OH oxidation of VOCs leads to peroxy radical formation and subsequent SOA production. Strong correlation between OH concentrations and ozone production.

bibliography.source_title: Monoterpenes are the largest source of summertime organic aerosol in the southeastern United States
bibliography.source_authors: Zhang, H., Yee, L. D., Lee, B. H., Curtis, M. P., Worton, D. R., Isaacman-VanWertz, G., et al.
bibliography.key_findings: Monoterpene SOA accounts for ~50% of summertime fine OA. NOx processing enhances monoterpene SOA mass. Both daytime OH oxidation and nighttime NO3 oxidation contribute to MTSOA formation.

bibliography.source_title: Disparities in precipitation effects on PM2.5 mass concentrations and chemical compositions: Insights from online monitoring data in Chengdu
bibliography.source_authors: Yi Li, Li Zhou, Hefan Liu, Song Liu, Miao Feng, Danlin Song, Qinwen Tan, Hongbin Jiang, Sophia Zuoqiu, Fumo Yang
bibliography.key_findings: Drizzle can exacerbate PM2.5 pollution under cleaner conditions (≤35 µg/m³). In spring, higher PM2.5 levels after drizzle were due to increased organic carbon concentrations favored by higher relative humidity and lower pH conditions, conducive to secondary organic aerosol production.

bibliography.source_title: Aerosol liquid water in PM2.5 and its roles in secondary aerosol formation at a regional site of Yangtze River Delta
bibliography.source_authors: Ruifang Shi, Fei Zhang, Yemin Shen, Jiasi Shen, Bingye Xu, Binyu Kuang, Zhengning Xu, Lingling Jin, Qian Tang, Xudong Tian, Zhibin Wang
bibliography.key_findings: ALWC contributed 66.68% to PM2.5 with higher mass-based growth factor when RH > 85%. Higher RH (>80%) promoted NO3- formation via gas-particle partitioning. Self-amplifying processes between ALWC and SIA enhanced particle mass growth.

bibliography.source_title: Improvement of inorganic aerosol component in PM2.5 by constraining aqueous-phase formation of sulfate in cloud with satellite retrievals: WRF-Chem simulations
bibliography.source_authors: Tong Sha, Xiaoyan Ma, Jun Wang, Rong Tian, Jianqi Zhao, Fang Cao, Yan-Lin Zhang
bibliography.key_findings: Sulfate, nitrate, ammonium, and PM2.5 concentrations all increase when fog dissipates (sulfate 23%, nitrate 24%, ammonium 14%, PM2.5 17% higher). Aqueous-phase formation of sulfate in clouds is underestimated by models.

bibliography.source_title: What rainfall rates are most important to wet removal of different aerosol types?
bibliography.source_authors: Yong Wang, Wenwen Xia, Guang J. Zhang
bibliography.key_findings: Precipitation frequency is more important than precipitation intensity for aerosol wet removal. Scavenging amount modes differ by aerosol size: 10-12 mm/d for Aitken, 8-9 mm/d for accumulation, 7-8 mm/d for coarse mode over tropics.

bibliography.source_title: Mutual promotion between aerosol particle liquid water and particulate nitrate enhancement leads to severe nitrate-dominated particulate matter pollution and low visibility
bibliography.source_authors: Yu Wang, Ying Chen, Zhijun Wu, Dongjie Shang, Yuxuan Bian, Zhuofei Du, Sebastian H. Schmitt, Rong Su, Georgios I. Gkatzelis, Patrick Schlag, Thorsten Hohaus, Aristeidis Voliotis, Keding Lu, Limin Zeng, Chunsheng Zhao, M. Rami Alfarra, Gordon McFiggans, Alfred Wiedensohler, Astrid Kiendler-Scharr, Yuanhang Zhang, Min Hu
bibliography.key_findings: Self-amplification effect between particulate nitrate and liquid water demonstrated. Mutual promotion can rapidly degrade air quality and halve visibility within 1 day. N2O5 uptake coefficient enhanced by factor of 9 (from 0.002 to 0.018) during haze development.

bibliography.source_title: Aqueous chemistry and its role in secondary organic aerosol (SOA) formation
bibliography.source_authors: Y. B. Lim, Y. Tan, M. J. Perri, S. P. Seitzinger, B. J. Turpin
bibliography.key_findings: SOA can form through reactions in atmospheric waters (clouds, fogs, aerosol water). In clouds reactions yield organic acids, in wet aerosols they yield large multifunctional humic-like substances via radical-radical reactions with O/C ratios near 1.

bibliography.source_title: Impacts of the East Asia monsoon on the PM2.5 acidity in Hanoi
bibliography.source_authors: Pham Duy Hien, Thu Bac Vuong, Ha Lan Anh, Quang Tran Vuong
bibliography.key_findings: Aerosol acidity is closely related to monsoon air masses in Hanoi. Fine particle pH driven by ammonium and sulfate from regional monsoon air masses. Provides context for Hanoi's PM2.5 characteristics during different monsoon seasons.

bibliography.source_title: Enhancement of PM2.5 Concentrations by Aerosol-Meteorology Interactions Over China
bibliography.source_authors: Xin Zhang, Qiang Zhang, Chaopeng Hong, Yixuan Zheng, Guannan Geng, Dan Tong, Yuxuan Zhang, Xiaoye Zhang
bibliography.key_findings: ACIs can increase PM2.5 concentration with more significant impacts in wet seasons via reduced wet scavenging and enhanced in-cloud chemistry. ARIs increase annual mean PM2.5 by 4.0 µg/m³, ACIs by 1.6 µg/m³.

bibliography.source_title: PM2.5 vertical variation during a fog episode in a rural area of the Yangtze River Delta, China
bibliography.source_authors: Jun Zhu, Bin Zhu, Yong Huang, Junlin An, Jiaping Xu
bibliography.key_findings: Fog greatly scavenged PM2.5 from 150 µg/m³ to 45 µg/m³ (~70% reduction). Turbulent mixing enhanced particle scavenging efficiency of fog droplets. Provides baseline for standard fog scavenging mechanism.

bibliography.source_title: Distinct Impacts of Light and Heavy Precipitation on PM2.5 Mass Concentration in Beijing
bibliography.source_authors: Sun, Y., Zhao, C., Su, Y., Ma, Z., Li, J., Letu, H., Yang, Y., Fan, H.
bibliography.key_findings: Light precipitation (<0.5mm) increases PM2.5 due to hygroscopic growth. Heavy precipitation (>10mm) decreases PM2.5 through scavenging. Threshold values identified: 0.5mm and 10mm. Scavenging efficiency depends on both precipitation amount and initial PM2.5 concentration.

bibliography.source_title: Impact of Precipitation with Different Intensity on PM2.5 over Typical Regions of China
bibliography.source_authors: Zhao, X., Sun, Y., Zhao, C., Jiang, H.
bibliography.key_findings: Three stages of removal effect identified: negative (<0.28-0.6 mm/h), neutral (0.28-2 to 0.6-4.5 mm/h), and positive (>2-5 mm/h). Regional differences in thresholds between BTH, YRD, and PRD. Hygroscopic growth competes with scavenging at low intensities.

bibliography.source_title: Multi-method determination of the below-cloud wet scavenging coefficients of aerosols in Beijing, China
bibliography.source_authors: Xu, D., Ge, B., Chen, X., Sun, Y., Cheng, N., Li, M., Pan, X., Ma, Z., Pan, Y., Wang, Z.
bibliography.key_findings: Below-cloud wet scavenging coefficients (BWSC) in range of 10^-5 s^-1. Exponential power relationship between BWSC and precipitation intensity. Greenfield gap (0.2-2.5 μm) shows higher observed BWSC than theoretical predictions. Field measurements show BWSC 1 order of magnitude higher than model calculations.

bibliography.source_title: The washout effects of rainfall on atmospheric particulate pollution in two Chinese cities
bibliography.source_authors: Guo, L.C., Zhang, Y., Lin, H., Zeng, W., Liu, T., Xiao, J., Rutherford, S., You, J., Ma, W.
bibliography.key_findings: Rainfall thresholds for PM2.5 washout: 7mm in Guangzhou, 1mm in Xi'an. Better washout effect for PM2.5-10 than PM2.5. PM2.5 reduction lasts 3 days (Guangzhou) to 6 days (Xi'an) after rain. Regional climate affects washout efficiency.

bibliography.source_title: Influence of meteorological conditions on PM2.5 and PM2.5−10 concentrations during the monsoon season in Hanoi, Vietnam
bibliography.source_authors: Hien, P.D., Bac, V.T., Tham, H.C., Nhan, D.D., Vinh, L.D.
bibliography.key_findings: In Hanoi, PM2.5 varies from 10 μg/m³ (rainy monsoon months June-August) to >300 μg/m³ (winter October-March). Rainfall and relative humidity largely control daily variations of PM2.5-10. Summer monsoon brings much lower particulate pollution than winter. Wind speed and temperature are key determinants of PM2.5.

bibliography.source_title: Insights into seasonal variation of wet deposition over southeast Asia via precipitation adjustment from the findings of MICS-Asia III
bibliography.source_authors: Itahashi, S., Ge, B., Sato, K., et al.
bibliography.key_findings: Wet deposition in Southeast Asia shows strong seasonal variation linked to monsoon precipitation patterns. Vietnam experiences significant wet deposition during monsoon season. Model inter-comparison reveals uncertainties in wet deposition simulation over Asia.

bibliography.source_title: Winter air pollution in Hanoi: Sources, meteorological influences and long-term trends
bibliography.source_authors: Phung-Ngoc et al.
bibliography.key_findings: Cold surge transport and local stagnation cause 30-40% PM2.5 increases; source shift from biomass to industrial

bibliography.source_title: Spatial and temporal variations of PM2.5 in Beijing
bibliography.source_authors: Zhao et al.
bibliography.key_findings: Diurnal bimodal pattern, wind direction effects, rural vs urban patterns

bibliography.source_title: Interaction between planetary boundary layer and PM2.5 pollution in megacities in China
bibliography.source_authors: Miao et al.
bibliography.key_findings: PBL-PM2.5 interactions, UHI effects, sea-land breeze, aerosol-PBL feedback

bibliography.source_title: Spatiotemporal distributions of rice residue burning in Vietnam
bibliography.source_authors: Lasko and Vadrevu
bibliography.key_findings: Rice straw burning emissions, pile vs non-pile burning, seasonal wind patterns

bibliography.source_title: Firework emissions and impacts on air quality in Metro Manila
bibliography.source_authors: Lorenzo et al.
bibliography.key_findings: Firework PM2.5 spikes, particle hygroscopicity changes, vertical distribution

bibliography.source_title: Transboundary PM2.5 in Northern Thailand during dry season
bibliography.source_authors: Inlaung et al.
bibliography.key_findings: Transboundary biomass burning contribution, March peak, ENSO effects

bibliography.source_title: Impact of urban expansion on the air pollution landscape: A case study of Hanoi, Vietnam
bibliography.key_findings: Mật độ dân số, mật độ đường và khoảng cách từ địa điểm giám sát đến trung tâm đô thị và tuyến đường gần nhất là các yếu tố thúc đẩy sự thay đổi nồng độ chất ô nhiễm tại Hà Nội.

bibliography.source_title: Evaluating the influence of land use and land cover change on fine particulate matter
bibliography.key_findings: Thứ tự nồng độ PM2.5 đối với các loại hình sử dụng đất: đất xây dựng > đất không sử dụng > mặt nước > đất nông nghiệp > đồng cỏ > rừng.

bibliography.source_title: Dry deposition effect of urban green spaces on ambient particulate matter pollution in China
bibliography.key_findings: Rừng lá rộng chiếm 89.22% hiệu quả lắng đọng khô trong không gian đô thị.

bibliography.source_title: Wintertime PM2.5 concentrations during persistent, multi-day cold-air pools in a mountain valley
bibliography.key_findings: Trong các sự kiện CAP, nồng độ PM2.5 có thể đạt tới 100 µg/m³. Nồng độ PM2.5 giảm tới 30% khi độ cao tăng từ 1300m lên 1600m.

bibliography.source_title: Influence of roadway emissions on near-road PM2.5: Monitoring data analysis and implications
bibliography.key_findings: Nồng độ PM2.5 gia tăng giảm 75% trong khoảng từ 5m đến 30m tính từ đường. Tác động tiêu cực đến sức khỏe đối với những người sống trong phạm vi 300m từ các tuyến đường chính.

bibliography.source_title: Intricate behavior of winter pollution in Hanoi over the 2006–2020 semi-climatic period
bibliography.source_authors: Bao-Anh Phung-Ngoc, Elsa Dieudonné, Hervé Delbarre, Karine Deboudt, Song-Tung Nguyen, Van-Hai Bui, Duc-Minh Vu, Huyen-Thu Nguyen-Thi
bibliography.key_findings: Cold surge onset causes ~30% PM2.5 increase via long-range transport; persistence phase causes ~40% increase via local stagnation; El Niño modifies air mass trajectories

bibliography.source_title: Influence of Northeast Monsoon cold surges on air quality in Southeast Asia
bibliography.source_authors: M.J. Ashfold, M.T. Latif, A.A. Samah, M.I. Mead, N.R.P. Harris
bibliography.key_findings: NEM cold surges elevate CO by >60% and O3 by >40% across Indochinese Peninsula

bibliography.source_title: Large-scale transport of PM2.5 in the lower troposphere during winter cold surges in China
bibliography.source_authors: Jianjun Wang, Meigen Zhang, Xiaolin Bai, Hongjian Tan, Sabrina Li, Jiping Liu, Rui Zhang, Mark A. Wolters, Xiuyuan Qin, Miming Zhang, Hongmei Lin, Yuenan Li, Jonathan Li, Liqi Chen
bibliography.key_findings: Cold surges transport PM2.5 up to 2000 km in 1-2 days at ground level; wind speeds over 20 m/s enable rapid transport

bibliography.source_title: Air pollution episodes associated with East Asian winter monsoons
bibliography.source_authors: P.D. Hien, P.D. Loc, N.V. Dao
bibliography.key_findings: ~12 multi-day pollution episodes per winter in Hanoi; NRTI and STI inversions trap pollutants; monsoon cycle controls pollution patterns

bibliography.source_title: Key factors explaining severe air pollution episodes in Hanoi during 2019 winter season
bibliography.source_authors: Bao Anh Phung Ngoc, Hervé Delbarre, Karine Deboudt, Elsa Dieudonné, Dien Nguyen Tran, Son Le Thanh, Jacques Pelon, François Ravetta
bibliography.key_findings: BLH <1000m on hazy days vs 700-1200m on cloudy days; severe events linked to LRT from China and stable conditions

bibliography.source_title: The effects of meteorological conditions and long-range transport on PM2.5 levels in Hanoi revealed from multi-site measurement using compact sensors and machine learning approach
bibliography.source_authors: Bich-Thuy Ly, Yutaka Matsumi, Tuan V. Vu, Kazuhiko Sekiguchi, Thu-Thuy Nguyen, Chau-Thuy Pham, Trung-Dung Nghiem, Ich-Hung Ngo, Yuta Kurotsuchi, Thu-Hien Nguyen, Tomoki Nakayama
bibliography.key_findings: Regional-scale meteorology dominates; PM2.5 co-varies across sites 60 km apart; LRT from north/northeast significant

bibliography.source_title: Characterizing PM2.5 in Hanoi with New High Temporal Resolution Sensor
bibliography.source_authors: Bich-Thuy Ly, Yutaka Matsumi, Tomoki Nakayama, Yosuke Sakamoto, Yoshizumi Kajii, Trung-Dung Nghiem
bibliography.key_findings: PM2.5 and CO increase several days after cold surge events; linked to East Asian winter monsoon

bibliography.source_title: The effects of meteorological conditions and long-range transport on PM2.5 levels in Hanoi revealed from multi-site measurement using compact sensors and machine learning approach
bibliography.source_authors: Ly, B.T., Matsumi, Y., Vu, T.V., et al.
bibliography.key_findings: Long-range transport from north and northeast significantly contributes to local PM2.5. Cold surge events increase pollutant levels over couple of days following the event.

bibliography.source_title: Effects of local, regional meteorology and emission sources on mass and compositions of particulate matter in Hanoi
bibliography.source_authors: Hai, C.D., Kim Oanh, N.T.
bibliography.key_findings: High PM levels observed at low wind speeds with stagnating ridge. Daily PM2.5 levels closely linked to wind direction relative to local emission sources.

bibliography.source_title: Chemical composition and potential sources of PM2.5 in Hanoi
bibliography.source_authors: Makkonen U., Vestenius M., Huy L.N., Anh N.T.N., Linh P.T.V., Thuy P.T., Phuong H.T.M., Nguyen H., Thuy L.T., Aurela M., Hellén H., Loven K., Kouznetsov R., Kyllönen K., Teinilä K., Kim Oanh N.T.
bibliography.key_findings: One third of PM2.5 mass was secondary inorganic aerosol dominated by sulphates. PMF analysis identified six source factors including local SIA (18%) and long-range transported SIA (25%). Highest daily PM2.5 concentrations occurred during winter with stagnant meteorological conditions.

bibliography.source_title: Fast sulfate formation from oxidation of SO2 by NO2 and HONO observed in Beijing haze
bibliography.source_authors: Wang J., Li J., Ye J., Zhao J., Wu Y., Hu J., Liu D., Nie D., Shen F., Huang X., Huang D.D., Ji D., Sun X., Xu W., Guo J., Song S., Qin Y., Liu P., Turner J.R., Lee H.C., Hwang S., Liao H., Martin S.T., Zhang Q., Jacob D.J.
bibliography.key_findings: Fog and cloud readily form under winter haze conditions, leading to high liquid water contents with high pH (>5.5) from elevated ammonia. Such conditions enable fast aqueous-phase oxidation of SO2 by NO2, producing HONO which can in turn oxidize SO2 to yield N2O. Sulfate shifts to larger particle sizes during fog/cloud processing.

bibliography.source_title: Aerosol high water contents favor sulfate and secondary organic aerosol formation from fossil fuel combustion emissions
bibliography.source_authors: Huang X., Liu Z., Ge Y., Li Q., Wang X., Fu H., Zhu J., Zhou B., Wang L., George C., Wang Y., Wang X., Su J., Xue L., Yu S., Mellouki A., Chen J.
bibliography.key_findings: Under conditions of RH exceeding 85%, multiphase oxidation of SO2 by in-particle nitrite/nitrous acid, generated through reactions involving aged EC-containing and iron-rich particles, as well as aqueous-phase formation of HMS, led to substantial increase in sulfate production. Aerosol LWC exhibited exponential increase with rising RH.

bibliography.source_title: Formation mechanisms of atmospheric nitrate and sulfate during the winter haze pollution periods in Beijing: gas-phase, heterogeneous and aqueous-phase chemistry
bibliography.source_authors: Liu P., Ye C., Xue C., Zhang C., Mu Y., Sun X.
bibliography.key_findings: Heterogeneous hydrolysis of N2O5 involving aerosol liquid water was responsible for nocturnal formation of nitrate at extremely high RH levels (≥60%). The oxidation pathway of H2O2 rather than NO2 was found to contribute greatly to aqueous-phase formation of sulfate. SOR values were extremely high during RH≥60% conditions.

bibliography.source_title: Aerosol pH and chemical regimes of sulfate formation in aerosol water during winter haze in the North China Plain
bibliography.source_authors: Tao W., Su H., Zheng G., Wang J., Wei C., Liu L., Ma N., Li M., Zhang Q., Pöschl U., Cheng Y.
bibliography.key_findings: Aerosol pH exhibited strong vertical gradient and distinct diurnal cycle. Over Beijing, average aerosol pH at surface layer was ~5.4. NO2 reaction pathway prevailed in megacity region at pH 4.5-5.7. TMI pathway dominated at pH 4-4.5. H2O2 pathway dominated at pH <4.5. Rapid sulfate production can be maintained over pH range 4.2-5.7.

bibliography.source_title: Particle phase state and aerosol liquid water greatly impact secondary aerosol formation: insights into phase transition and its role in haze events
bibliography.source_authors: Meng X. et al.
bibliography.key_findings: During haze episodes, transformation rates of sulfate and nitrate aerosols rapidly increase through phase transition and increased ALW by 48%. Phase transition from solid to liquid state at high RH reduces kinetic limitation on heterogeneous reactions.

bibliography.source_title: Modelling the partitioning of ammonium nitrate in the convective boundary layer
bibliography.source_authors: Aan de Brugh J.M.J. et al.
bibliography.key_findings: Ammonium nitrate and ammonium sulphate behave differently with varying temperature and relative humidity. Ammonium sulphate resides exclusively in the particle phase, while ammonium nitrate partitions between gas and particle phases. Low temperature and high RH favor particle-phase ammonium nitrate.

relationships.description: Aerosol pH controls dominant sulfate formation pathway: NO2/O3 at pH>4.5, TMI/H2O2 at pH<4.5
relationships.mechanism: Aerosol pH controls the dominant sulfate formation pathway. At pH > 4.5, S(IV) oxidation by NO2 and O3 dominates, while at pH < 4.5, oxidation by H2O2 and transition metal ions (TMI) becomes dominant. Lower pH enhances SO2 uptake and aqueous-phase oxidation kinetics through increased Henry's law solubility.

conditions.original_text: pH range: 4.2-5.7 for rapid sulfate production

normalized.interpretation: Optimal pH range for rapid sulfate production with pathway transitions
Minimum RH required for aerosol liquid water to be present
Sufficient SO2 precursor for sulfate formation

relationships.quantitative_effect: Rapid sulfate production maintained over pH 4.2-5.7 with pathway transitions
relationships.notes: pH exhibits strong vertical gradient: ~5.4 at surface to ~0 at 3km altitude

relationships.description: Mn-catalyzed SO2 oxidation on aerosol surfaces is dominant sulfate formation pathway during haze
relationships.mechanism: Manganese-catalyzed oxidation of SO2 on aerosol surfaces is the dominant sulfate formation pathway during haze. Mn(III) acts as intermediate that oxidizes S(IV). The reaction involves: SO2 + O2 + Mn(OH)x → SO5·- + Mn2+, followed by HSO5- formation and sulfate production with NH3. This heterogeneous surface reaction is 1-2 orders of magnitude faster than aqueous-phase routes.

normalized.interpretation: Optimal RH range for Mn-catalyzed surface oxidation
Experimental temperature condition, approximately 25°C
Requires manganese ions in aerosol phase
Requires ammonia for neutralization step

relationships.quantitative_effect: Sulfate formation rate: 14.1-24.5 μg m-3 h-1; contributes 69.2% ± 5.0% of particulate sulfur
relationships.notes: Reaction inhibited by more acidic conditions; pH is critical factor

relationships.description: High ALWC provides reaction medium for enhanced aqueous-phase chemistry and SIA formation
relationships.mechanism: High aerosol liquid water content (ALWC) provides reaction medium for enhanced aqueous-phase chemistry. ALWC promotes aging of EC-containing particles and facilitates SOA formation. Under high RH (>85%), multiphase oxidation of SO2 by in-particle nitrite/HONO and HMS formation leads to substantial sulfate increase. ALWC enhances gas uptake by increasing effective Henry's law constants.

normalized.interpretation: Threshold RH for significant aqueous-phase chemistry enhancement
Requires particles capable of water uptake (sulfate, nitrate, ammonium)
Requires NO2 or HONO as oxidants

relationships.description: Mineral dust provides catalytic surfaces for SO2 oxidation with NO2 synergy
relationships.mechanism: Mineral dust provides catalytic surfaces for SO2 oxidation. NO2 and SO2 have synergistic effects when reacting on mineral dust surfaces (Al2O3, CaO, ZnO, TiO2, Fe2O3, MgO). Coexistence of NO2 significantly promotes oxidation of surface sulfite to sulfate, with O2 as the key oxidant. This reduces atmospheric environmental capacity for SO2.

normalized.interpretation: Requires mineral dust particles in atmosphere
Synergistic effect requires both NO2 and SO2 present
O2 is always available in atmosphere - implicit condition

relationships.source_quote: coexistence with NOx can reduce the environmental capacity for SO2, leading to rapid conversion of SO2 to sulfate because NO2 and SO2 have a synergistic effect when they react on the surface of mineral dust
relationships.quantitative_effect: PM2.5 peak concentrations over 300 μg/m³ during dust-influenced haze episodes
relationships.notes: Combined motor vehicle exhaust and coal-fired emissions reduce atmospheric capacity for SO2

relationships.description: AWC regulates NH4+ partitioning creating self-amplifying feedback for SNA formation
relationships.mechanism: Aerosol water content (AWC) regulates gas-particle partitioning of ammonia (ε(NH4+)), which plays a critical role in secondary inorganic aerosol (SNA) formation. Higher AWC leads to higher ε(NH4+), which increases SNA, which in turn increases AWC - creating a self-amplifying feedback mechanism. This explains why ammonia emission reduction alone may not effectively reduce SNA.

normalized.interpretation: High ammonia concentration environment

conditions.original_text: RH sufficient for aerosol water formation

normalized.interpretation: Requires sufficient RH for AWC, but no specific threshold given in source

Ring-breaking oxidation of POA aromatic species (polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons - PAHs) leads to functionalization as carbonyls and carboxylic acids, forming secondary organic aerosol (aq-SOA). This pathway is significant for fossil-fuel derived SOA.

This pathway becomes dominant in megacity regions like Beijing. The NO2 pathway prevails in areas with high NOx emissions and moderately acidic to neutral aerosol conditions.

At RH > 85%, particles take up significant water, providing medium for aqueous-phase chemistry. Hygroscopic particles (containing sulfate, nitrate, ammonium) show enhanced water uptake, creating positive feedback for secondary aerosol formation.

relationships.mechanism: Aerosol liquid water enables aqueous-phase formation of hydroxymethanesulfonate (HMS) from reaction of S(IV) with formaldehyde (HCHO). relationships.mechanism: Iron-rich particles, particularly those containing oxalate, facilitate SO2 oxidation through catalytic processes. Fe(III) can catalyze S(IV) oxidation in aqueous phase. Iron solubility and speciation (Fe3+-Fe2+ cycling) depend on dust mineralogy, particle acidity, and heterogeneous redox reactions.

relationships.description: SO2 is oxidized in aqueous phase by H2O2, O3, or NO2 to form sulfate
relationships.mechanism: SO2 bị oxy hóa trong pha nước (aqueous-phase oxidation) bởi các chất oxy hóa như H2O2, O3, hoặc NO2. Phản ứng chính: SO2 + H2O → H2SO3 → HSO3- + H+. HSO3- sau đó bị oxy hóa thành SO4^2- (sulfate). Tốc độ phản ứng với H2O2 nhanh nhất ở pH thấp, trong khi phản ứng với O3 và NO2 nhanh hơn ở pH cao (>5.5).

relationships.source_quote: Atmospheric oxidation of sulfur dioxide (SO2) forms sulfate-containing aerosol particles that impact air quality, climate, and human and ecosystem health. It is well-known that in-cloud oxidation of SO2 frequently dominates over gas-phase oxidation on regional and global scales.
relationships.notes: Cơ chế này áp dụng toàn cầu nhưng đặc biệt quan trọng ở các khu vực có độ ẩm cao như Hà Nội.

relationships.description: NO2 oxidizes dissolved SO2 (S(IV)) to sulfate (S(VI)) in aqueous phase, producing HONO as byproduct
relationships.mechanism: NO2 hòa tan vào pha nước và oxy hóa SO2 (dạng S(IV)) thành sulfate (S(VI)) theo phản ứng: S(IV) + 2NO2(aq) + H2O → S(VI) + 2H+ + 2NO2-. Phản ứng này tạo ra HONO (nitrous acid) như sản phẩm phụ. Tốc độ phản ứng tăng mạnh khi pH > 5.5 do nồng độ S(IV) (chủ yếu là SO3^2-) tăng.

relationships.source_quote: Aqueous-phase oxidation of S(IV) by NO2 (aq) in fog is an alternative explanation for the depletion of NO2 and produces both HONO and sulfate. We find an SO2 e-folding lifetime of 1–7 min against loss by reaction (R2).

relationships.mechanism: Nhiệt độ ảnh hưởng đến hằng số phân ly của NH4NO3. Ở nhiệt độ thấp, cân bằng dịch chuyển về phía pha hạt (NH4NO3 solid/aqueous). Hằng số phân ly tăng theo hàm mũ với nhiệt độ.

NH3 cũng ảnh hưởng đến pH của aerosol liquid water, từ đó ảnh hưởng đến tốc độ các phản ứng aqueous-phase. Nồng độ NH3 cao duy trì pH > 5.5, thúc đẩy phản ứng oxy hóa SO2 bởi NO2.

relationships.source_quote: The mean gaseous ammonia concentration observed during Stage II was 14 ppb. Fog has a much higher pH than haze under high-ammonia conditions because of efficient scavenging of ammonia at high LWC. Whereas ammonia volatility limits the pH of haze aqueous solutions to a 4–5 range even with ammonia in large excess, the corresponding pH range in fog is 6–7.

relationships.description: Secondary Inorganic Aerosol (sulfate, nitrate, ammonium) contributes 25-43% of PM2.5 mass during pollution episodes in Hanoi
relationships.mechanism: Secondary Inorganic Aerosol (SIA) bao gồm sulfate, nitrate và ammonium là thành phần chính của PM2.5, đặc biệt trong các đợt ô nhiễm không khí. SIA đóng góp 25-43% khối lượng PM2.5 tại Hà Nội trong các đợt ô nhiễm. SIA được hình thành từ các phản ứng hóa học của các tiền chất khí (SO2, NOx, NH3) trong khí quyển.
relationships.source_title: Influence of Secondary Inorganic Aerosol on the Concentrations of PM2.5 and PM0.1 during Air Pollution Episodes in Hanoi, Vietnam
relationships.source_quote: The results showed that SIA contributed on average 29.0% and 14.1%, respectively, to PM2.5 and PM0.1 concentrations during air pollution episodes at HUST. Those were higher than the average contribution percentages of total SIA to PM concentrations in non-episode periods for PM2.5 (25.6%) and PM0.1 (10.6%) at HUST.
relationships.notes: Đóng góp của SIA cao hơn trong các đợt ô nhiễm so với các ngày bình thường.

relationships.source_quote: Multiphase oxidation involving aerosol particles, fog, and cloud droplets has been generally thought to scale with liquid water content (LWC). The major oxidation pathways which are considered to contribute to sulphate formation in the aqueous phase are oxidation by H2O2 and oxidation by O3.
relationships.notes: H2O2 là chất oxy hóa quan trọng trong mây và sương mù, nhưng nồng độ có thể bị giới hạn trong điều kiện ô nhiễm nặng.

source_quotes.quote: During cold surge onsets, long-range transport from China causes an average increase of ~30% in PM2.5 concentrations.
PM2.5 driven by cold surges from the ground level could travel up to 2000 km from northern to southern China within two days.
The most prominent surface feature of the winter monsoon is cold surges induced by strong northwesterly winds along the eastern flank of the Siberian high.

source_quotes.quote: During cold surge onsets, long-range transport from China causes an average increase of ~30% in PM2.5 concentrations.
The most prominent surface feature of the winter monsoon is cold surges induced by strong northwesterly winds along the eastern flank of the Siberian high.

source_quotes.quote: The stagnation of local pollution during the cold surges persistence causes an average increase of ~40% in level of PM2.5.
A dozen multi-day pollution episodes occur from October to February in Hanoi, Vietnam due to prolonged anticyclonic conditions established after the northeast monsoon surges.
Type I is caused by the arrival of the cold surge in GBK, which leads to the development of stagnant conditions favorable for haze formation.

normalized.interpretation: Relationship active during persistence phase of cold surge
Cold surge events occur during winter monsoon season

normalized.interpretation: Low wind speed enables local pollution accumulation

source_quotes.quote: WPEs are associated with nighttime radiation temperature inversions (NRTIs) in the dry phase and subsidence temperature inversions (STIs) in the humid phase.

BLH proved to be one of the key factors controlling air pollution in Hanoi. The lower BLH on the hazy days weakened the vertical mixing and was directly related to an increase in aerosol concentrations at the surface.
In NRTI periods, the pollution level is about two times higher at night than in daytime.

normalized.interpretation: Relationship active during persistence phase of cold surge
Cold surge events occur during winter monsoon season

conditions.original_text: Hanoi, Vietnam and Red River Delta region

normalized.interpretation: Primary applicability to Hanoi urban area

conditions.original_text: Boundary layer height below 1000m during hazy days

normalized.interpretation: Shallow BLH suppresses vertical mixing

conditions.original_text: Temperature inversion present (NRTI in dry phase or STI in humid phase)

normalized.interpretation: NRTI = Nighttime Radiation Temperature Inversion (dry phase), STI = Subsidence Temperature Inversion (humid phase)

source_quotes.quote: The PM2.5 peak, which often appeared at night after a cold surge, may be the result of secondary particle formation under stagnant conditions.
Daily levels of PM2.5 and CO increased several days after most cold surge events.
It has been found that air pollutant levels increased over the couple of days that followed a cold surge.

source_quotes.quote: The 24-h pollutant concentrations are lowest during cold surges; concurrently rise thereafter reaching the highest levels toward the middle of a monsoon cycle, then decline ahead of the next cold surge.
Each monsoon cycle usually proceeds through a dry phase and a humid phase as Asiatic continental cold air arrives in Hanoi through inland China then via the East China Sea.

sources.source_title: Large-scale transport of PM2.5 in the lower troposphere during winter cold surges in China
sources.source_authors: Wang, J., Zhang, M., Bai, X., et al.

source_quotes.quote: PM2.5 driven by cold surges from the ground level could travel up to 2000 km from northern to southern China within two days.
Wind speed was found to be a major facilitator in transporting PM2.5 from Beijing to Xiamen.
This finding is a new long-range transport mechanism comparing to the well-established mechanism, with long-range transport more likely to occur in the upper troposphere than at lower levels.

normalized.interpretation: Relationship active during onset phase of cold surge
Cold surge events occur during winter monsoon season

relationships.description: Non-linear (inverted U-shaped) relationship between RH and PM2.5: accumulation at RH<70%, removal at RH>70%
relationships.mechanism: Mối quan hệ giữa độ ẩm và PM2.5 có dạng chữ U ngược. Ở độ ẩm thấp đến trung bình (RH < 70%), độ ẩm thúc đẩy các phản ứng hóa học thứ cấp (ví dụ: chuyển đổi SO2 và NO2 thành sulfate và nitrate), làm tăng nồng độ PM2.5. Tuy nhiên, ở độ ẩm rất cao (RH > 70%), các quá trình lắng đọng ướt (wet deposition) trở nên chiếm ưu thế, dẫn đến việc loại bỏ các hạt khỏi khí quyển và làm giảm nồng độ PM2.5.

normalized.description: Piecewise relationship: accumulation regime (RH<70%) OR removal regime (RH>70%)
normalized.fix_reason: Compound condition referencing piecewise children; individual children are checkable, not the compound wrapper

conditions.original_text: Có sự hiện diện của các tiền chất như SO2 và NO2

normalized.description: Requires presence of SO2 and NO2 precursors for secondary aerosol formation

relationships.source_title: Relationships of relative humidity with PM2.5 and PM10 in the Yangtze River Delta, China
relationships.source_authors: Cairong Lou, Hongyu Liu, Yufeng Li, Yan Peng, Juan Wang & Lingjun Dai
relationships.source_quote: Our results revealed that RH had an inverted U-shaped relationship with PM2.5 concentrations (peaking at RH = 45–70%)... The very-dry (RH < 45%), dry (RH = 45–60%) and low-humidity (RH = 60–70%) conditions positively affected PM2.5 and exerted an accumulation effect, while the mid-humidity (RH = 70–80%), high-humidity (RH = 80–90%), and extreme-humidity (RH = 90–100%) conditions played a significant role in reducing particle concentrations.
relationships.notes: EDGE CASE: Non-linear relationship (Inverted U-shaped). Phá vỡ quy tắc chung rằng độ ẩm cao luôn làm giảm PM2.5. Hiệu ứng đảo ngược tại ngưỡng RH khoảng 70%.

embedding_context.summary: Relative Humidity moderator Pm25: Mối quan hệ giữa độ ẩm và PM2.5 có dạng chữ U ngược. Ở độ ẩm thấp đến trung bình (RH < 70%), độ ẩm thúc đẩy các phản ứng hóa học thứ cấp (ví dụ: chuyển đổi SO2 và NO2 thành sulfate và nitrate), làm tă...

relationships.description: Drizzle has negative removal effect on PM2.5, potentially increasing concentrations
relationships.mechanism: Mưa phùn (drizzle) có hiệu ứng loại bỏ âm (negative removal effect) đối với PM2.5, nghĩa là nó có thể làm tăng nồng độ. Điều này xảy ra do các giọt mưa phùn nhỏ không đủ lớn để gây ra sự lắng đọng hiệu quả (washout) mà thay vào đó, chúng có thể làm tăng độ ẩm gần bề mặt, thúc đẩy sự hình thành aerosol thứ cấp và sự phát triển hút ẩm (hygroscopic growth) của các hạt hiện có, dẫn đến nồng độ khối lượng cao hơn.

normalized.description: Precipitation type must be drizzle (light, fine droplets)
Low precipitation intensity typical of drizzle (<2.5 mm/h based on WMO classification)

relationships.source_title: Effect of precipitation on reducing atmospheric pollutant over Beijing
relationships.source_authors: Zuofang Zheng, Guirong Xu, Qingchun Li, Conglan Chen, Jiangbo Li
relationships.source_quote: The removal effect of drizzle on PM2.5 and PM10 was negative, and the removal effect of moderate rain and heavy rain was significantly higher than that of light rain.
relationships.notes: EDGE CASE: Exception. Phá vỡ quy tắc chung rằng mưa luôn làm sạch không khí. Mưa phùn có thể làm tăng PM2.5.

embedding_context.summary: Precipitation direct Pm25: Mưa phùn (drizzle) có hiệu ứng loại bỏ âm (negative removal effect) đối với PM2.5, nghĩa là nó có thể làm tăng nồng độ. Điều này xảy ra do các giọt mưa phùn nhỏ không đủ lớn để gây ra sự lắng đọng hiệ...

relationships.description: Cold surge causes delayed PM2.5 peak 2-5 days after passage due to post-surge stable stratification
relationships.mechanism: Một đợt không khí lạnh (cold surge) ban đầu làm sạch không khí do gió mạnh. Tuy nhiên, sau khi đợt không khí lạnh đi qua, khối không khí lạnh còn sót lại tạo ra một lớp nghịch nhiệt ổn định ở tầng thấp. Lớp này bẫy các chất ô nhiễm phát thải sau đó, kết hợp với điều kiện gió yếu, dẫn đến sự tích tụ nhanh chóng và một đỉnh nồng độ PM2.5 mới, thường xảy ra vài ngày sau sự kiện không khí lạnh ban đầu.

conditions.original_text: Sau khi một đợt không khí lạnh đi qua (giai đoạn suy yếu)

relationships.source_title: Characterizing PM2.5 in Hanoi with New High Temporal Resolution Sensor
relationships.source_quote: Large increases in both PM2.5 and CO were frequently observed several days after cold surges... During five days after the cold surges, peaks of PM2.5 were appeared at night. High hourly levels of PM2.5 (higher than 120 μg m⁻³) appeared at the fourth day after the cold surge and a level higher than 160 μg m⁻³ were observed at the fifth day after the cold surge.
relationships.notes: EDGE CASE: Non-linear relationship (Delayed effect). Phá vỡ quy tắc chung rằng không khí lạnh và gió mạnh luôn làm giảm ô nhiễm. Hiệu ứng làm sạch ban đầu bị đảo ngược sau vài ngày.

embedding_context.summary: Cold Surge direct Pm25: Một đợt không khí lạnh (cold surge) ban đầu làm sạch không khí do gió mạnh. Tuy nhiên, sau khi đợt không khí lạnh đi qua, khối không khí lạnh còn sót lại tạo ra một lớp nghịch nhiệt ổn định ở tầng thấ...

relationships.description: Strong winds can increase PM2.5 at receptor sites via long-range transport from polluted source regions
relationships.mechanism: Trong điều kiện ô nhiễm, gió mạnh không phải lúc nào cũng làm phân tán ô nhiễm. Nếu gió thổi từ một khu vực nguồn ô nhiễm nặng, nó có thể vận chuyển một lượng lớn PM2.5 đến một khu vực tiếp nhận (receptor region), dẫn đến sự gia tăng đột ngột nồng độ PM2.5 tại địa phương. Hiệu ứng này đặc biệt rõ rệt khi có sự vận chuyển tầm xa (long-range transport).

normalized.description: High wind speed enabling long-range transport
normalized.note: Threshold approximate; varies by region and source distance

conditions.original_text: Hướng gió từ khu vực nguồn ô nhiễm

conditions.original_text: Khu vực đang trong tình trạng ô nhiễm (polluted conditions)

relationships.source_title: Effect of Vertical Wind Shear on PM2.5 Changes over a Receptor Region in Central China
relationships.source_quote: The correlation between wind speed and PM2.5 was negative for clean conditions and positive for polluted conditions in both two sites... Prevailed northerly wind disrupted the local circulation and enhanced the surface PM2.5 concentrations under polluted conditions, which tend to be an indicator of regional transport of air pollutants.

relationships.description: High RH causes hygroscopic growth of particles, leading to overestimation by light-scattering sensors
relationships.mechanism: Các cảm biến PM2.5 chi phí thấp dựa trên phương pháp tán xạ ánh sáng (light scattering) thường không có chức năng kiểm soát độ ẩm. Ở độ ẩm cao, các hạt PM2.5 có tính hút ẩm (hygroscopic) sẽ hấp thụ hơi nước, làm tăng kích thước và thay đổi chỉ số khúc xạ của chúng. Điều này khiến chúng tán xạ nhiều ánh sáng hơn, và cảm biến sẽ diễn giải sai điều này thành một nồng độ khối lượng (mass concentration) cao hơn thực tế. Đây là một sai số đo lường (measurement artifact), không phải là sự gia tăng thực sự của khối lượng hạt khô.

conditions.original_text: Sử dụng cảm biến PM2.5 dựa trên tán xạ ánh sáng

normalized.description: Sensor must use light scattering principle (optical sensors)

conditions.original_text: Cảm biến không có bộ phận làm khô hoặc kiểm soát độ ẩm

normalized.description: Sensor lacks RH control or drying mechanism
High relative humidity where hygroscopic growth becomes significant

relationships.source_title: Hygroscopic properties of particulate matter and effects of their interactions with weather on visibility
relationships.source_quote: An important reason for the lower accuracies is that low-cost sensors lack the RH and temperature control functions; therefore, light scattering sensors overestimate the PM concentration affected by humidity.
relationships.notes: EDGE CASE: Measurement Artifact. Các cảm biến quang học đánh giá quá cao nồng độ PM2.5 ở độ ẩm cao do sự phát triển hút ẩm của hạt, không phải do sự gia tăng thực tế về khối lượng.

embedding_context.summary: Relative Humidity artifact Pm25 Measurement: Các cảm biến PM2.5 chi phí thấp dựa trên phương pháp tán xạ ánh sáng (light scattering) thường không có chức năng kiểm soát độ ẩm. Ở độ ẩm cao, các hạt PM2.5 có tính hút ẩm (hygroscopic) sẽ hấp thụ hơ...

relationships.description: Strong sunlight with high precursors causes photochemical smog and secondary PM2.5 formation
relationships.mechanism: Bức xạ mặt trời mạnh trong điều kiện có nồng độ cao các tiền chất (NOx, VOCs, SO2) thúc đẩy các phản ứng quang hóa tạo ra ozone và aerosol hữu cơ thứ cấp (SOA). Các phản ứng này dẫn đến sự hình thành PM2.5 thứ cấp, gây ra các đợt ô nhiễm sương mù quang hóa (photochemical smog) với nồng độ PM2.5 và O3 cao đồng thời.

normalized.description: Strong solar radiation enabling photochemical reactions
normalized.note: Threshold approximate; photochemistry significant above ~400-600 W/m²

normalized.note: Threshold approximate; reactions faster at higher temperatures

relationships.source_title: Estimation of Secondary Organic Aerosol Formation During a Photochemical Smog Episode in Shanghai, China
relationships.source_quote: This study focuses on a pollution episode of PM2.5 that occurred simultaneously with an O3 episode in Shanghai in the summer of 2013... This suggests the importance of the photochemical formation of PM2.5 during a pollution episode. OC accounted for 28.9% of PM2.5, making it the most abundant component, and its concentration was well correlated with O3 (R2 = 0.72). The concentration of secondary OC (SOC) was estimated by the elemental carbon-tracer method, and the result showed that SOC accounted for 48.7% of OC on average, indicating that secondary formation was the main source of OC.
relationships.notes: EDGE CASE: Exception. Phá vỡ quy tắc chung rằng thời tiết nắng, quang đãng đồng nghĩa với không khí trong lành. Trong điều kiện có nhiều tiền chất, nắng nóng lại là tác nhân chính gây ra ô nhiễm PM2.5 nghiêm trọng.

relationships.description: Fog droplets are detected as particles by light-scattering PM sensors, causing measurement overestimation
relationships.mechanism: Fog droplets are liquid aerosols that scatter light similarly to solid particles. Light-scattering PM sensors cannot distinguish between fog droplets and actual PM particles, leading to false positive readings.

normalized.note: This condition applies to sensor hardware, not environmental variables

relationships.notes: This is a measurement artifact, not actual pollution increase. Critical for data quality assessment.

relationships.description: High RH causes hygroscopic particle growth, leading to sensor overestimation of PM2.5
relationships.mechanism: At very high RH (>85%), hygroscopic particles absorb water and grow in size, increasing their light-scattering cross-section. This causes light-scattering sensors to overestimate PM mass concentrations.

normalized.interpretation: High humidity threshold for significant hygroscopic growth

normalized.note: Requires chemical speciation data

relationships.description: Fog provides aqueous-phase environment for rapid SO2 oxidation
relationships.mechanism: Fog droplets provide high liquid water content (LWC) environment where SO2 dissolves and is rapidly oxidized by NO2, HONO, H2O2, and O3. The high pH (>5.5) from elevated ammonia enables fast aqueous-phase oxidation.

quantitative_evidence.description: Sulfate production rate in cloud water can reach 0.5-1.3 μg m⁻³ h⁻¹

relationships.notes: This is actual chemistry, not measurement artifact. Produces real PM2.5 increase.

relationships.mechanism: Rapid aqueous-phase oxidation of SO2 produces sulfate, while similar processes convert NOx to nitrate. These secondary inorganic aerosols (SIA) contribute significantly to PM2.5 mass.

embedding_context.summary: Sia Formation direct cause Pm25: Secondary inorganic aerosols (sulfate, nitrate, ammonium) directly contribute to PM2.5 mass. These hygroscopic species also promote further water uptake, creating positive feedback.

relationships.description: Intense solar radiation drives photolysis reactions producing oxidants
relationships.mechanism: Intense solar radiation (especially UV) drives photolysis reactions that produce hydroxyl radicals (OH) and other oxidants. These oxidants initiate the oxidation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs).

normalized.interpretation: Clear sky allows maximum solar radiation

normalized.note: Can be proxied by solar_radiation intensity

normalized.interpretation: Peak solar radiation hours

relationships.source_quote: At lower pollution levels, the intense solar radiation caused substantial and rapid production of OOA (O/C = 0.81) and intermediate VOCs (both in a high oxidation state) at a rate of 15.0% h⁻¹ and 14.0% h⁻¹, respectively.

quantitative_evidence.description: OOA production rate 15.0% h⁻¹, intermediate VOCs at 14.0% h⁻¹

relationships.notes: Photochemistry peaks during midday hours

embedding_context.summary: Solar Radiation direct cause Photochemistry: Intense solar radiation (especially UV) drives photolysis reactions that produce hydroxyl radicals (OH) and other oxidants. These oxidants initiate the oxidation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs).

relationships.description: Photochemical oxidation of VOCs produces secondary organic aerosol
relationships.mechanism: Photochemical oxidation of VOCs by OH radicals produces low-volatility oxidized organic compounds that partition into the particle phase, forming secondary organic aerosol (SOA).

relationships.source_quote: These results highlight the feedback effects between radiation and moisture in terms of altering the formation mechanism of secondary aerosols.

quantitative_evidence.description: Highly oxygenated OOA (O/C = 0.81) formed rapidly under strong solar radiation

relationships.notes: SOA formation rate depends on NOx regime (VOC-limited vs NOx-limited)

embedding_context.summary: Photochemistry direct cause Soa Formation: Photochemical oxidation of VOCs by OH radicals produces low-volatility oxidized organic compounds that partition into the particle phase, forming secondary organic aerosol (SOA).

relationships.description: Clear sky conditions lead to higher PM2.5 than cloudy conditions
relationships.mechanism: Clear sky conditions enhance photochemistry and SOA formation. Additionally, clear sky is often associated with stagnant high-pressure systems that trap pollutants near the surface.

Low PBLH traps pollutants near surface

relationships.mechanism: At RH above 40-60%, particles transition from semi-solid/solid state to liquid state. This occurs when aerosol liquid water (ALW) mass fraction exceeds 15% of dry mass.

embedding_context.summary: Relative Humidity direct cause Particle Phase Transition: At RH above 40-60%, particles transition from semi-solid/solid state to liquid state. This occurs when aerosol liquid water (ALW) mass fraction exceeds 15% of dry mass.

relationships.mechanism: Liquid particles enable faster heterogeneous and aqueous-phase reactions. Gas-phase species can more easily partition into liquid particles and undergo aqueous-phase oxidation.

relationships.description: Secondary aerosol production increases particle hygroscopicity
relationships.mechanism: Production of secondary inorganic aerosols (sulfate, nitrate) and oxidized organic aerosols increases particle hygroscopicity, enabling more water uptake.

relationships.description: Cloud cover reduces solar radiation reaching surface through reflection and scattering
relationships.mechanism: Cloud cover (đặc biệt là overcast conditions với cloud fraction >70%) làm giảm lượng solar radiation đến bề mặt thông qua hai cơ chế: (1) phản xạ (reflection) ánh sáng mặt trời trở lại không gian, và (2) tán xạ (scattering) ánh sáng trong các hạt nước của mây. Quá trình này làm giảm cả shortwave radiation ban ngày và thay đổi longwave radiation balance ban đêm.

normalized.interpretation: Cloud fraction exceeds 70%
Presence of cloud liquid water required for scattering

relationships.description: Reduced solar radiation leads to decreased surface temperature
relationships.mechanism: Khi solar radiation đến bề mặt giảm do cloud cover, năng lượng hấp thụ bởi bề mặt đất giảm theo, dẫn đến giảm nhiệt độ bề mặt (surface temperature). Điều này làm giảm gradient nhiệt độ giữa bề mặt và khí quyển, ảnh hưởng đến sự phát triển của convective boundary layer.

normalized.interpretation: Daytime hours when solar radiation is present
Shortwave radiation is reduced compared to clear-sky conditions

relationships.source_quote: API and ARF reduced the daytime shortwave radiative fluxes at the surface by 92.4–102.9 W m−2
relationships.notes: Step 2 of chain. Quantified reduction: 92-103 W/m² decrease in surface shortwave radiation.

embedding_context.summary: Reduced Solar Radiation direct cause Reduced Surface Heating: Khi solar radiation đến bề mặt giảm do cloud cover, năng lượng hấp thụ bởi bề mặt đất giảm theo, dẫn đến giảm nhiệt độ bề mặt (surface temperature). Điều này làm giảm gradient nhiệt độ giữa bề mặt và ...

relationships.description: Reduced surface heating leads to stable atmospheric stratification
relationships.mechanism: Giảm nhiệt độ bề mặt làm giảm sự phát triển của turbulent mixing và convection trong boundary layer. Khi bề mặt không được làm nóng đủ, không khí gần mặt đất không có đủ năng lượng để nổi lên, dẫn đến điều kiện khí quyển ổn định (stable stratification) với reduced vertical mixing.

normalized.interpretation: Daytime hours
Surface heating is weak due to reduced solar radiation
Wind speed below 2 m/s reduces mechanical mixing

relationships.source_title: Impacts of atmospheric circulation patterns and cloud inhibition on aerosol radiative effect and boundary layer structure during winter air pollution in Sichuan Basin, China
relationships.source_quote: Clouds reduce solar radiation through reflection and scattering, resulting in more stable stratification and aerosol accumulation.
relationships.notes: Step 3 of chain. Stable stratification inhibits vertical mixing.

embedding_context.summary: Reduced Surface Heating direct cause Atmospheric Stability: Giảm nhiệt độ bề mặt làm giảm sự phát triển của turbulent mixing và convection trong boundary layer. Khi bề mặt không được làm nóng đủ, không khí gần mặt đất không có đủ năng lượng để nổi lên, dẫn đến...

relationships.description: Stable atmospheric conditions suppress boundary layer growth
relationships.mechanism: Điều kiện khí quyển ổn định (stable atmospheric conditions) ức chế sự phát triển của convective boundary layer, dẫn đến giảm planetary boundary layer height (PBLH). PBLH thấp hơn có nghĩa là thể tích không khí có sẵn để pha loãng chất ô nhiễm bị giảm đáng kể.

normalized.interpretation: Atmosphere is stably stratified, inhibiting convection
Turbulent kinetic energy is low
Wind speed below 2 m/s

relationships.description: Decreased PBLH concentrates pollutants in smaller volume
relationships.mechanism: Khi PBLH giảm, thể tích không khí trong boundary layer giảm, trong khi emissions vẫn tiếp tục. Điều này dẫn đến tăng nồng độ PM2.5 do hiệu ứng concentration (cùng lượng chất ô nhiễm trong thể tích nhỏ hơn). Đồng thời, reduced vertical mixing ngăn cản sự phân tán của chất ô nhiễm lên cao.

normalized.interpretation: Planetary boundary layer height below 500 meters
Emission sources continue to release pollutants
Vertical mixing is suppressed due to stable conditions

relationships.description: Decreased cloud cover at night enhances surface longwave radiation loss
relationships.mechanism: Ban đêm, khi cloud cover giảm, bề mặt mất nhiệt nhanh hơn thông qua longwave radiation emission vào không gian. Mây thường trap longwave radiation và radiate nó trở lại bề mặt (greenhouse effect), nhưng khi không có mây, bề mặt cooling được tăng cường đáng kể.

normalized.interpretation: Nighttime hours when longwave radiation dominates

conditions.original_text: Clear sky or low cloud cover (<30%)

normalized.interpretation: Cloud fraction below 30% allows enhanced longwave emission
Low humidity enhances radiative cooling

relationships.description: Strong surface cooling creates temperature inversion layer
relationships.mechanism: Surface radiation cooling mạnh làm cho bề mặt lạnh hơn không khí phía trên, tạo ra temperature inversion (nghịch nhiệt) - một lớp không khí ấm hơn nằm trên lớp không khí lạnh gần mặt đất. Inversion này hoạt động như một 'nắp' ngăn cản sự phân tán thẳng đứng của chất ô nhiễm.

normalized.interpretation: Nighttime hours
Surface temperature drops significantly due to radiative cooling
Clear or mostly clear sky
Wind speed below 2 m/s reduces mechanical mixing

relationships.description: Temperature inversion traps pollutants near surface
relationships.mechanism: Temperature inversion tạo ra một lớp không khí ổn định ngăn cản sự trộn lẫn thẳng đứng. Chất ô nhiễm phát thải gần mặt đất bị giữ lại dưới lớp inversion, không thể phân tán lên cao, dẫn đến tích tụ PM2.5 trong lớp không khí gần mặt đất.

normalized.interpretation: Temperature inversion layer exists
Emission sources continue to release pollutants
Wind speed below 2 m/s

relationships.description: Solar UV radiation drives photolysis of atmospheric molecules
relationships.mechanism: Solar radiation (đặc biệt là UV radiation trong dải 290-400 nm) cung cấp năng lượng photon cần thiết để phá vỡ các liên kết hóa học trong các phân tử như NO2, O3, HONO, H2O2, và các organic peroxides. Quá trình photolysis này là bước khởi đầu cho các phản ứng photochemistry trong khí quyển.

normalized.interpretation: Solar radiation is present (daytime)
UV-A and UV-B wavelengths required for photolysis

conditions.original_text: Clear sky or partly cloudy conditions

normalized.interpretation: Cloud cover below 70% allows sufficient UV penetration

relationships.source_quote: This paper demonstrates that OH radicals are formed by photolysis of secondary organic aerosol (SOA) material formed by terpene ozonolysis.
relationships.notes: Step 1 of photochemistry chain: solar_radiation → photolysis → radical_formation → oxidation_reactions → soa_formation → pm25

embedding_context.summary: Solar Radiation direct cause Photolysis: Solar radiation (đặc biệt là UV radiation trong dải 290-400 nm) cung cấp năng lượng photon cần thiết để phá vỡ các liên kết hóa học trong các phân tử như NO2, O3, HONO, H2O2, và các organic peroxides....

relationships.description: Photolysis of O3, HONO, H2O2 produces OH radicals
relationships.mechanism: Photolysis của các phân tử như O3 (tạo O(1D) + H2O → 2OH), HONO (→ OH + NO), H2O2 (→ 2OH), và organic hydroperoxides (ROOH → RO + OH) tạo ra hydroxyl radicals (OH). OH radical là chất oxy hóa chính trong khí quyển, khởi đầu hầu hết các phản ứng oxy hóa VOCs.

normalized.interpretation: UV radiation present for photolysis

conditions.original_text: Precursor molecules present (O3, HONO, H2O2, ROOH)

normalized.interpretation: Photolysis precursors (O3, HONO, H2O2, ROOH) must be present
Daytime hours
